Detailed Description

template<class ObjectType, class EvaluatorType>
class stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >

This class defines all behavior of the SlimTree. Probably most of the atributes will be stored in the header page of the used stPageManager (stDiskPageManager or stMemoryPageManager).

First implementation is based on original code by Agma Traina, Bernard Seeger and Caetano Traina

Main modifications from original code are intent to turn it an object oriented compliant code.

Author
Fabio Jun Takada Chino (chino.nosp@m.@icm.nosp@m.c.sc..nosp@m.usp..nosp@m.br)
Marcos Rodrigues Vieira (mrvie.nosp@m.ira@.nosp@m.icmc..nosp@m.sc.u.nosp@m.sp.br)
Josiel Maimone de Figueiredo (josie.nosp@m.l@ic.nosp@m.mc.sc.nosp@m..usp.nosp@m..br)
Todo:
More documentation.
Version
1.0

Definition at line 822 of file stSlimTree.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
enum stSlimTree::tChooseMethod

These constants are used to define the choose sub tree method.

Enumerator
cmBIASED 

Choose the first of the qualifying nodes.

cmRANDOM 

Randomly choose one of the qualifying nodes.

cmMINDIST 

Choose the node that has the minimum distance from the new object and the representative (center) of the node.

cmMINOCCUPANCY 

Choose the node that has the minimum occupancy among the qualifying ones. This is the default method due to its better performance.

cmMINGDIST 

Unknown.

Todo:
Discover what this method do.

Definition at line 746 of file stSlimTree.h.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
enum stSlimTree::tCorrectMethod

These constants are used to define the correction method.

Enumerator
crmOFF 

No correction.

crmFATFACTOR 

Use Fat Factor.

Definition at line 777 of file stSlimTree.h.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
enum stSlimTree::tSplitMethod

These constants are used to define the split method.

Todo:
Update documentation of each constant.
Enumerator
smRANDOM 

This method peeks 2 random objects as the representatives and distribute the other objects around them.

This is the fastest split method but the result is undetermined.

smMINMAX 

The optimal split method. This algorithm tries all possible distribution configurations and select the optimal distribution as the final result.

This is the default method for the M-Tree.

Warning
This method is very slow.
smSPANNINGTREE 

Split method based on the Minimal Spanning Tree algorithm. This is the Slim-Tree default split method.

Definition at line 792 of file stSlimTree.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::stSlimTree ( stPageManager *  pageman)

Creates a new metric tree using a given page manager. This instance will not claim the ownership of the given page manager. It means that the application must dispose the page manager when it is no loger necessary.

Parameters
pagemanThe bage manager to be used by this metric tree.
template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >

)

Parameters
pagemanThe bage manager to be used by this metric tree.
metricEvalThe shared metric evaluator be used by this metric tree.
Warning
metricEval will not be delete by this class.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::FarthestQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)

This method will perform a K-Farthest Neighbor query using a global priority queue based on chained list to "enhance" its performance. We believe that the use of a priority queue during the search in the index nodes will force the radius to converge faster than the normal farthest query.

This implementation may replace the original implementation if it proves to be better.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
tieThe tie list. Default false.
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void FarthestQuery

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
stDistance stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::GetDistanceLimit ( )
virtual

Returns the limit distance between 2 objects in the tree. That is . In other words, there is no distance greater than this.

This value may be the greatest distance between objects but may return greater values due to implementation optmizations.

Reimplemented from stMetricTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

Definition at line 1015 of file stSlimTree.h.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::IncrementalListNearestQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)

This method will inicializate the parameters to perform a K-Nearest Neighbor query using a global priority queue based on a dynamic link list.

This method is based on Hjaltson and Samet (ACM TODS-2000). It is possible to get k+1 object after retrieve the k's objects.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
tieThe tie list. Default false.
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void IncrementalNearestQuery

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
void stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::IncrementalNearestQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stCount  k,
tResult *  result,
tPGenericHeap *  globalQueue 
)

This method will perform a K-Nearest Neighbor query using a global priority queue based on a dynamic heap to "enhance" its performance.

This method is based on Hjaltson and Samet (ACM TODS-2000). It is possible to get k+1 object after retrieve the k's objects.

This is possible because the global priority is not delete and the subtrees are not pruned.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
Theresult.
globalQueuea queue to be managed.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
The instance of tPGenericHeap must be created and destroied by user.
This method must be called after InitializeIncrementalNearestQuery.
See also
void InitializeIncrementalNearestQuery

stCount  k,
tResult *  result,
tGenericPriorityQueue *  globalQueue 
)

This method will perform a K-Nearest Neighbor query using a global priority queue based on a dynamic list.

This method is based on Hjaltson and Samet (ACM TODS-2000). It is possible to get k+1 object after retrieve the k's objects.

This is possible because the global priority is not delete and the subtrees are not pruned.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
Theresult.
globalQueuea queue to be managed.
Warning

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::KAndRangeQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stDistance  range,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)
virtual

This method will perform a range query with a limited number of results.

This query is a combination of the standard Range Query and the standard K-Nearest Neighbor Query. All objects which matches both conditions will be included in the result. The K-Nearest Neighbor Query is implemented with a local priority queue.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
rangeThe range of the results.
kThe maximum number of results.
tieThe tie list. This parameter is optional. Default false;
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void KAndRangeQuery
Warning
This method does not work for trees with only one node.

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::KOrRangeQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stDistance  range,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)
virtual

This method will perform range query with a limited number of results.

This query is a combination of the standard range query and the standard K-Nearest Neighbor Query. All objects which matches with one of two conditions will be included in the result. The K-Nearest Neighbor Query is implemented with a local priority queue.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
rangeThe range of the results.
kThe maximum number of results.
tieThe tie list. This parameter is optional. Default false;
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void KOrRangeQuery
Warning
This method does not work for trees with only one node.

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::KRingQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stDistance  inRange,
stDistance  outRange,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)
virtual

This method will perform a ring query with K-Nearest Neighbor query. The result will be a set of pairs object/distance.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
inRangeThe outter range of the results.
outRangeThe inner range of the results.
kThe number of nearest neighbor.
tieThe tie list. This parameter is optional. Default false;
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
The value of outRange must be higher than inRange.
See also
void RingKQuery()

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::LazyRangeQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stDistance  range,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)

This method will perform a range query with a limited number of results.

A lazy range query recovers the k elements within a radius, independently if the k elements are the k nearest elements of query object.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
rangeThe range of the results.
kThe maximum number of results.
tieThe tie list. This parameter is optional. Default false;
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void LazyRangeQuery
template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::ListNearestQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)

This method will perform a K-Nearest Neighbor query using a link list. We believe that the use of a priority queue during the search in the index nodes will force the radius to converge faster than the normal nearest query.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
tieThe tie list. Default false.
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::NearestQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)
virtual

This method will perform a K-Nearest Neighbor query using a global priority queue based on chained list to "enhance" its performance. We believe that the use of a priority queue during the search in the index nodes will force the radius to converge faster than the normal nearest query.

This implementation may replace the original implementation if it proves to be better.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
kThe number of neighbors.
tieThe tie list. Default false.
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void NearestQuery

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
virtual void stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::Optimize ( )
virtual

Optimizes the structure of this tree by executing the Slim-Down algorithm.

The Slim-Down algorithm can only be performed when the tree has at least 3 levels. Fortunately, this

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::PointQuery ( ObjectType *  sample)
virtual

This method will return the object in the tree that has the distance 0 to the query object. In other words, the query object itself.

If there are more elements that has distance 0 to the query object, this method will return the first found.

The object pointed by sample will not be destroyed by this method.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
This method return only one object that has distance 0 to the query object.
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.

Reimplemented from stMetricAccessMethod< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >.

template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
tResult* stSlimTree< ObjectType, EvaluatorType >::SimpleKOrRangeQuery ( ObjectType *  sample,
double  fractalDimension,
stDistance  radiusKOrRange,
stCount  k,
bool  tie = false 
)

This method will perform the disjunctive complex similarity query between range and k-nearest neighbor operator. However, in this method, this is done through of range queries.

This query is a combination of the standard range query and the standard K-Nearest Neighbor Query. All objects which matches with one of two conditions will be included in the result. The K-Nearest Neighbor Query is implemented with a global priority queue.

Parameters
sampleThe sample object.
fractalDimensionThe fractal dimension of the data set.
nroObjectsThe total number of objects of the data set.
radiusKOrRangeTh radius of the range operator.
kThe maximum number of results.
tieThe tie list. This parameter is optional. Default false;
Returns
The result or NULL if this method is not implemented.
Warning
The instance of tResult returned must be destroied by user.
See also
void KOrRangeQuery
template<class ObjectType , class EvaluatorType >
